{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} [[File:Anthonyweiner.jpg|thumb|right|Anthony Weiner, Congressional portrait, {{circa|2007}}]] [[Anthony Weiner]] is a former member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[New York City]] who has been involved in multiple sex scandals related to [[sexting]].
The first scandal began when Weiner was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[United States Congress|U.S. Congressman]]. He used the [[social media]] website [[Twitter]] to send a link that contained a sexually suggestive picture of himself to a 21-year-old woman. After initially denying reports that he had posted the image, he admitted that he sent a link to the photo. He also sent additional sexually explicit photos and messages to women before and during his marriage. He denied ever having met or having had a physical relationship with any of the women. On June 16, 2011, Weiner announced his intention to resign from Congress effective June 23.
Weiner returned to politics in April 2013 when he entered the [[New York City mayoral election, 2013|New York City mayoral race]]. After additional pictures of Weiner were released, Weiner admitted sexting at least three women since his resignation from Congress. He remained in the race until the end, placing fifth in the Democratic primary.
Following a report from the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' in September 2016, the [[FBI]] investigated Weiner for sexting with a 15-year-old girl. His laptop was seized and emails related to the [[Hillary Clinton email controversy]] were found on it, causing a controversy late in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|presidential election]]. On May 19, 2017, Weiner pled guilty to one count of transferring obscene material to a minor. His wife, [[Huma Abedin]], filed for divorce prior to Weiner's guilty plea. In September, he was sentenced to 21 months in federal prison. On November 6, 2017, Weiner began his sentence at [[Federal Medical Center, Devens]], in [[Ayer, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/11/06/us/weiner-reports-to-prison/index.html|title=Anthony Weiner reports to prison|last=CNN|first=Jean Casarez,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-09-27}}</ref> His release date is scheduled for 2019.
==Initial media reports and Weiner's denial== On May 27, 2011, Weiner used his public Twitter account to send a link to a photo on [[yfrog]].<ref name="nymag photo"/><ref name="nypost_110605"/> The picture of his [[erection|erect penis]] concealed by [[boxer briefs]]<ref name="nymag photo"/><ref name="troubling tweet"/><ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=nypost_110605/> was sent to a 21-year-old female college student from [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]],<ref name="student embroiled"/> who was following his posts on the [[social media]] website.<ref name="whose crotch"/> Though the link was quickly removed from Weiner's Twitter account, screen shots of Weiner’s original message and of the photo were captured by a user identified as "Dan Wolfe" on Twitter and subsequently sent to blogger [[Andrew Breitbart]] who published them on his [[BreitbartTV|BigGovernment]] website the following day.<ref name=Behind>{{cite web |last1=Muñoz-Temple |first1=Amanda |title=The Man Behind Weiner's Resignation |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/the-man-behind-weiner-s-resignation-20110616 |website=National Journal |accessdate=January 4, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702002145/http://www.nationaljournal.com/the-man-behind-weiner-s-resignation-20110616 |archivedate=July 2, 2015 |date=June 16, 2011|dead-url=yes}}</ref> CNN described it as a "lewd photograph" of a "man bulge in ... underwear".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1106/16/cnr.05.html|title=CNN.com - Transcripts|website=edition.cnn.com|accessdate=May 19, 2017}}</ref>
On June 1, 2011, Weiner gave a series of interviews in which he denied sending the photo and suggested that someone, perhaps a political opponent, had hacked into his accounts and published the photo.<ref name="emotional apology"/> Weiner also said he could not say "with certitude" that the photo was not of him. He suggested that the image might be doctored, saying, "Maybe it did start being a photo of mine and now looks something different or maybe it is from another account."<ref name="cantor says"/><ref name="maybe it started"/><ref name="blitzer interview"/> He did not ask the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] or [[United States Capitol Police|U.S. Capitol Police]] to investigate the incident<ref name = polprobe/> but said he had retained a private security firm to look into this matter because he felt it was a prank, not a crime.<ref name="can't say"/> Several bloggers accused Wolfe and Breitbart of planting the photo and message as part of a scheme to defame Weiner.<ref>[http://www.nationaljournal.com/the-man-behind-weiner-s-resignation-20110616 The Man Behind Weiner's Resignation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130702000000/http://www.nationaljournal.com/the-man-behind-weiner-s-resignation-20110616 |date=July 2, 2013 }}; ''National Journal''; Amanda Muñoz-Temple; June 16, 2011</ref>
Evidence later revealed that a group of self-described conservatives<ref name="news" /> had been monitoring Weiner's communications with women for at least three months. Two false identities of underage girls had been created by unknown parties to solicit communication with Weiner and the women he was contacting.<ref name="news">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/nyregion/fake-identities-were-used-on-twitter-to-get-information-on-weiner.html?_r=1 |author=Preston, Jennifer |date=June 17, 2011 |title=Fake Identities Were Used on Twitter in Effort to Get Information on Weiner |work=The New York Times |accessdate=July 12, 2011}}</ref> Bloggers reported a tweet made in April by a 17-year-old [[Delaware]] girl in which she exclaimed, "Seriously talking to Representative Weiner from New York right now! Like is my life real?" In early June, [[Fox News Channel]], whose reporter "happened to be there when the cops showed up", reported that police went to the girl's house to question her and her parents. The police, who had been "made aware of an alleged contact" between Weiner and the girl, also reviewed content on her computer. Weiner confirmed having communicated with the girl, but denied sending any inappropriate messages. The family of the girl stated the contact was "not salacious or in any manner inappropriate". The police did not find anything wrong in Weiner's communications with the girl.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Anthony Weiner admits contact with girl, 17|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0611/56740.html|date=June 10, 2011|first=Maggie|last=Haberman|work=[[Politico]]|first2=Jonathan|last2=Allen|accessdate=June 1, 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/06/12/weiner%E2%80%99s-17-year-old-twitter-contact-responds/ Weiner’s 17-year-old Twitter contact responds]; CNN; June 12, 2011</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Weinergate: Cops probe Rep. Anthony Weiner's Tweets to minor, pol's team says it was G-rated|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/weinergate-cops-probe-rep-anthony-weiner-tweets-minor-pol-team-g-rated-article-1.129271|date=June 11, 2011|first=Alison|last=Gendar|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York|first2=Reuven|last2=Blau|first3=Corky|last3=Siemaszko|accessdate=June 1, 2013}}</ref> The entire incident was later dubbed "Weinergate."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/william-bradley/weinergates-lasting-impac_b_872585.html|title=William Bradley: Weinergate's Lasting Impact: The First Big Social Media Political Sex Scandal|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=June 17, 2011|date=June 7, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Debra|last=Alfarone |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/wpix-women-of-weinergate,0,829543.story |title=The Women of Weinergate: Anthony Weiner's Sexting Mates|work=Chicago Tribune|date=June 7, 2011|accessdate=June 17, 2011}}</ref>
===Admission=== On June 6, Breitbart posted a [[Cropping (image)|cropped]], shirtless picture of Weiner that was obtained from a second woman on the Internet,<ref name=Behind /><ref name="half-naked"/><ref name="corbett"/> and said that Weiner had sent more pictures of himself, including at least one that was sexually graphic.<ref name=autogenerated2/> After this information had been made public, Weiner held a press conference in New York and apologized, saying, "I have not been honest with myself, my family, my constituents, my friends and supporters, and the media" and that, "to be clear, the picture was of me, and I sent it."<ref name="transcript"/> After being prompted by reporters, he specifically apologized to Andrew Breitbart.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weiner: 'I apologize to Andrew Breitbart'|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/onmedia/0611/Weiner_I_apologize_to_Andrew_Breitbart.html|publisher=Politico|accessdate=July 19, 2014|date=June 6, 2011}}</ref> He also said he had "engaged in several inappropriate conversations conducted over Twitter, [[Facebook]], [[email]] and occasionally on the phone" and had exchanged "messages and photos of an explicit nature with about six women over the last three years". He added he had never met or had a physical relationship with any of them. He said he was "deeply ashamed" of his "terrible judgment and actions", which he called "very dumb."<ref name=pressconftransc/>
When Weiner answered questions, he said that he had the continuing support of his wife Huma Abedin, who was a long-time aide to [[Hillary Clinton]].<ref name="unflappable"/> He had married Abedin in July 2010 in a ceremony officiated by [[Bill Clinton]], and he said that he did not intend to resign his congressional seat.<ref name="admits internet"/> Prior to his marriage, Weiner was known for his "bachelor exploits with some of New York's most eligible women," detailed in a 2011 ''[[Moment (magazine)|Moment]]'' profile of the Congressman.<ref name="live from NY"/> Following the revelations of his inappropriate communications, his reportedly emotional apology to former president Clinton was referred to in the press as highly ironic.<ref name="clintons unhappy"/> Asked about an allegation that he had engaged in [[phone sex]] with a woman in [[Nevada]], Weiner neither confirmed nor denied the statement, saying that though he did not want to impinge the privacy of any of the women, neither would he contradict any of their statements.<ref name = pressconftransc/> At his press conference, Weiner did admit that he had exchanged the reported [[Sexting|sexting messages]] with his accuser.<ref name=pressconftransc/><ref name="nydnsp"/>
===Later events=== During an appearance on [[Sirius XM]] radio on June 8, 2011, Breitbart showed hosts [[Opie and Anthony]] a photograph of what he claimed to be Weiner's nude genitalia. One of the cameras in the room caught the cell phone's display, and the hosts subsequently leaked the photo by publishing it on Twitter.<ref name="by opie"/> Breitbart stated that the photo was published without his permission, and later told [[KFI]] radio, "These people have admitted that they did this surreptitiously and illicitly and they lied in the process saying that they didn't even have a camera in the place."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/anthony-weiners-genitalia-photo-puts-196386|title=Anthony Weiner's Genitalia Photo Puts Sirius XM in Sticky Situation (Video)|last=Bond|first=Paul|date=June 9, 2011|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=June 18, 2011}}</ref> Weiner's spokesperson issued the following statement: "As Representative Weiner said on Monday when he took responsibility for his actions, he has sent explicit photos."<ref name="democrats push"/>
News media also reported the identity of other Weiner's social media contacts, Lisa Weiss, a 40-year-old [[blackjack]] dealer in [[Las Vegas]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2011/06/06/2011-06-06_rep_anthony_weiners_sexting_partners_meagan_broussard_lisa_weiss_out_themselves_.html#ixzz1RwtOJCEv|author=Hartenstein, Meena|date=June 6, 2011|title=Rep. Anthony Weiner's sexting partners Meagan Broussard, Lisa Weiss out themselves, describe affairs|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=July 12, 2011}}</ref> and 28-year-old porn actress Ginger Lee<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/15/us-usa-politics-weiner-pornstar-idUSTRE75E3N820110615|author=Nichols, Michelle|date=June 15, 2011|title=Porn star says Representative Weiner asked her to lie|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=July 12, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Weiner text pal Ginger Lee set to strip again tonight|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/weiner_text_pal_ginger_lee_set_to_yXeWmBUG4i8BAslXMYEI3L|date=June 15, 2011|first=Jeane|last=MacIntosh|work=[[New York Post]]|first2=Jeremy|last2=Olshan|accessdate=April 27, 2013}}</ref> who had exchanged sexually oriented messages with Weiner. On June 15, Ginger Lee held a press conference during which she said that when she requested advice from Weiner on how to respond to the media, he had advised her on June 2 that if they both stayed quiet the scandal would die down.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/15/us-usa-politics-weiner-pornstar-idUSTRE75E3N820110615|title=Porn star says Representative Weiner asked her to lie|agency=Reuters|accessdate=June 16, 2011}}</ref>
===Political and constituent reaction=== On the afternoon of June 6, 2011, [[House Minority Leader]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] called for an investigation by the [[House Ethics Committee]] to determine "whether any official resources were used or any other violation of House rules occurred".<ref name="peleth"/> A number of Democratic and Republican congressmen called for Weiner's resignation.<ref name="boehner silent"/> On June 7, [[Republican National Committee Chairman]] [[Reince Priebus]] called for him to resign, and challenged Pelosi to suggest the same. [[House Majority Leader]] [[Eric Cantor]] (R, VA) said he should resign, opining: "The last thing we need is to be immersed in discussion about Congressman Weiner and his Twitter activities."<ref name="repres"/> House Democrats who called for him to resign on June 8 included Representatives [[Allyson Schwartz]] (PA), [[Mike Ross (politician)|Mike Ross]] (AR), [[Mike Michaud]] (ME), [[Niki Tsongas]] (MA), [[Larry Kissell]] (NC) and [[Joe Donnelly]] (IN).<ref name="democrats step"/>
On June 11, Nancy Pelosi, [[Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee|DCCC]] [[Steve Israel]], and [[Democratic National Committee|DNC]] Chair [[Debbie Wasserman Schultz]] called for Weiner's resignation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/06/nancy_pelosi_i_urge_weiner_to.html|title=Weiner Enters 'Treatment Center' As Pelosi, Top Dems Urge Him to Quit|work=New York|accessdate=June 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2011/06/11/dnc-chairwoman-debbie-wasserman-schultz-calls-on-weiner-to-resign|author=Nelson, Steven|date=June 11, 2011|title=Wasserman Schultz, Pelosi call on Weiner to resign|publisher=The Daily Caller|accessdate=July 12, 2011}}</ref> Weiner requested and was granted a short leave of absence from the House to obtain professional treatment of an unspecified nature.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/11/anthony-weiner-treatment_n_875422.html?icid=maing-grid7%7Cmaing6%7Cdl1%7Csec1_lnk2%7C70084|title=Anthony Weiner To Seek Treatment|work=The Huffington Post|date=June 11, 2011|accessdate=June 12, 2011|first=Elyse|last=Siegel}}</ref>
Two June 6 surveys of New York City adult residents provided conflicting results. A TV station [[NY1]] and [[Marist College]] poll indicated that 51% believed Weiner should remain in Congress, 30% thought he should step down, and 18% were unsure.<ref name=autogenerated3/> A WABC-TV/SurveyUSA automated survey found the city divided, with 46 percent who thought he should resign and 41 percent who thought he should stay in office.<ref name="huffingtonpost1"/> On June 9, a NY1-Marist Poll showed that 56% of registered voters in Weiner's [[New York's 9th congressional district|Congressional District]] wanted him to stay in Congress, and 33% thought he should resign, with 12% uncertain. In the same poll, 73% said he acted unethically, but not illegally.<ref name="nypost1"/>
On June 13, [[White House]] spokesman [[Jay Carney]] said "The president feels... this is a distraction, as Congressman Weiner has said himself, his behavior was inappropriate; dishonesty was inappropriate."<ref name="CNN white house"/> President [[Barack Obama]] said in an interview later that day that if he were Weiner, he would resign.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/13/obama-anthony-weiner-resign_n_876327.html|title=Obama On Anthony Weiner: If I Were Him I'd Resign|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=June 13, 2011|first=Elyse|last=Siegel|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623115121/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/13/obama-anthony-weiner-resign_n_876327.html|archivedate=June 23, 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref>
===Resignation=== On June 16, 2011, Weiner announced he would resign his seat in Congress. He made the announcement at a news conference in Brooklyn, at the same location where he announced his first campaign for New York City Council in 1992.<ref name=hasntofficially/><ref>See: * {{cite news|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/16/even-a-media-circus-needs-a-clown|date=June 16, 2011 |title=Even a Media Circus Needs a Clown|author=Parker, Ashley|accessdate=December 6, 2011|work=The New York Times}} * [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43425251/ns/politics-capitol_hill "New York Rep. Anthony Weiner resigns"], msnbc.com; retrieved June 16, 2011. * {{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Transcript-of-Weiner-Announcing-Resignation-from-Congress.html|title=Transcript of Weiner Announcing Resignation from Congress|work=NBC New York|date=June 16, 2011}} * {{cite news|first1=Andrea|last1=Canning|first2=Jessica|last2=Hopper|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/sexting-scandal-rep-anthony-weiner-tweet-facebook-photos/story?id=13770641|title=Rep. Anthony Weiner's Sexting Scandal: Why Did He Do It?|publisher=ABC News|date=June 6, 2011|accessdate=June 17, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Morales |first=Mark |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-06-07/local/29648552_1_anthony-weiner-sexting-scandal-brooklyn |title=Anthony Weiner's sexting scandal gets big thumbs down in Queens, Brooklyn |work=New York Daily News |date=June 7, 2011 |accessdate=June 17, 2011 }} * {{cite news |url=http://amfix.blogs.cnn.com/2011/06/08/will-rep-weiners-career-survive-the-sexting-scandal |title=Will Rep. Weiner's career survive the sexting scandal? |publisher=Amfix.blogs.cnn.com |date=June 8, 2011 |accessdate=June 17, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720221958/http://amfix.blogs.cnn.com/2011/06/08/will-rep-weiners-career-survive-the-sexting-scandal |archivedate=July 20, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref>
On June 20, Weiner formally submitted his letter of resignation from the U.S. House of Representatives, effective at midnight on June 21.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Camia|first=Catalina|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2011/06/anthony-weiner-resignation-sex-scandal-/1|title=Anthony Weiner officially steps down Tuesday|work=USA Today|accessdate=June 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=June 20, 2011|title=Document Drop: Weiner's Resignation Letter|first=Celeste|last=Katz|work=New York Daily News|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/2011/06/document-drop-weiners-resignation-letter|quote=Dear Secretary Perales and Governor Cuomo: I hereby resign as the Member of the House of Representatives for New York's Ninth Congressional District effective at midnight, Tuesday, June 21, 2011. It has been an honor to serve the people of Queens and Brooklyn.}} (scan of letter of resignation at this link)</ref> His letter of resignation was read on the floor of the House of Representatives on June 23 and entered into the record.<ref name=hasntofficially>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2011/06/anthony-weiner-resignation-sex-scandal-/1|work=USA Today|date=July 20, 2011|title=Anthony Weiner hasn't officially resigned yet|first=Catalina|last=Camia}}</ref><ref>See: * {{ cite news |title=House recognizes Weiner's resignation |url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/house_recognizes_weiner_resignation-206765-1.html |work=Roll Call |last=Stanton |first=John |date=June 24, 2011 }} * {{cite news |work=NY1 |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/news_beats/politics/141564/weiner-s-resignation-read-in-congress |title=Weiner's Resignation Read In Congress |date=June 23, 2011 }} (video link) * {{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/06/16/house-dems-may-boot-weiner-from-committee |title=Weiner to Resign from Congress |publisher=Fox News |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=June 17, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713103112/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/06/16/house-dems-may-boot-weiner-from-committee |archivedate=July 13, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref>
{{Anchor|Special election}}In a special election held on September 13, 2011 to fill the vacant seat, the Republican candidate, businessman [[Bob Turner (American politician)|Bob Turner]], defeated the Democratic candidate, State Assemblyman [[David Weprin]].<ref> [http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/09/14/republican-wins-house-race-in-new-york-seen-as-obama-rebuke/#ixzz1Xtl4cbZK Republican Wins House Race in New York, Seen as Obama Rebuke], foxnews.com, September 14, 2011; accessed August 29, 2016.</ref>
==2013 mayoral race and second scandal== In April 2013, the former congressman announced his return to politics as [[New York City mayoral election, 2013|candidate for mayor of New York City]]. He soon became the front runner against Democratic primary-opponent City Council Speaker [[Christine Quinn]].<ref name="wsj-poll_130626"/>
On July 23, 2013, more pictures and sexting allegedly by Weiner were released by the website ''The Dirty''.<ref name="Thedirty.com"/><ref name="guardian"/> They were allegedly sent under the alias "'''Carlos Danger'''" to a 22-year-old woman named with whom Weiner had contact in late 2012, as late as April 2013,<ref name="guardian"/> more than a year after Weiner left Congress. The woman's identity had yet to be confirmed. At a news conference that same day, with his wife Huma by his side, Weiner responded, "I said that other texts and photos were likely to come out, and today they have." He also said he would not drop out of the mayoral election for the City of New York.<ref>{{cite news|title=Weiner still in NYC race despite improper messages|last=Moore|first=Martha T.|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/07/23/weiner-more-lewd-messages/2579631|work=[[USA Today]]|date=July 23, 2013}}</ref>
On July 24 Weiner's sexting partner's identity was confirmed as Sydney Leathers<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/07/24/weiner-resists-calls-to-withdraw-as-woman-who-received-messages-is-identified/|title=Weiner resists calls to withdraw as woman who received messages is identified|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> on CNN by a personal friend. Later ''The New York Times'' print edition called for Weiner to withdraw from the mayoral race in an editorial titled "Mr. Weiner and the Elusive Truth".<ref name="elusive"/> In a joint [[NBC 4 New York]]/''[[Wall Street Journal]]''/[[Marist Poll|Marist Institute for Public Opinion]] poll taken that day, Weiner's favorability rating had dropped over 20 points, and he had lost the lead in the primary race to councilor Quinn, now leading him 25 to 16 percent.<ref name="politico"/>
On July 25, the New York ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' reported that, at a news conference in Brooklyn that day, Weiner admitted that he had sexted with three women in the months after his resignation from Congress, and that there had been six to ten women involved in total, not "dozens and dozens".<ref name="NYDN"/> Weiner’s campaign manager Danny Kedem quit the weekend after the news conference.<ref>{{cite news|title=Weiner’s Campaign Manager Quits|first=Michael|last=Barbaro|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/28/nyregion/weiners-campaign-manager-quits.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 27, 2013|accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref>
Following the primary election on September 10, 2013, the press reported that Sydney Leathers, the young woman at the center of the second scandal, attempted to enter Weiner's campaign party that night, without an invitation.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/election/sydney-leathers-attempts-crash-anthony-weiner-election-party-article-1.1451641|title=Sydney Leathers, former sexting partner of Anthony Weiner, attempts to crash his election night party|accessdate=September 11, 2013|location=New York|work=Daily News}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2013/09/11/sydney-leathers-crashes-sexting-partner-anthony-weiner-concession-party|title=Sydney Leathers crashes sexting partner Anthony Weiner's concession party|accessdate=September 11, 2013|work=Fox News|date=September 11, 2013}}</ref> Weiner lost decisively in the election, finishing in fifth place with 4.9% of the vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/2013/nyc-primary-results|title=Live Results: New York City Primary Elections|work=[[Huffington Post]]|date=September 11, 2013|first=Aaron|last=Bycoffe}}</ref>
==Criminal conviction and divorce== On August 28, 2016, the ''[[New York Post]]'' reported that Weiner had engaged in sexting with another woman, including sending one picture in July 2015 while lying in bed with his toddler son sleeping next to him.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Anthony Weiner sexted busty brunette while his son was in bed with him|url=https://nypost.com/2016/08/28/anthony-weiner-sexted-busty-brunette-while-his-son-was-in-bed-with-him|date=August 28, 2016|accessdate=August 28, 2016}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported the next day that Weiner and his wife intended to separate.<ref>{{Citenews|title=Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedin to Separate After His Latest Sexting Scandal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/30/nyregion/anthony-weiner-sexting-huma-abedin.html?_r=0|date=August 29, 2016|accessdate=August 29, 2016}}</ref> Weiner had served as a contributor to [[NY1]], which put him on indefinite leave.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/08/29/media/weiner-ny1-nydn/index.html|title=NY1 puts Anthony Weiner on indefinite leave|first=Dylan|last=Byers|publisher=CNN.com|date=August 29, 2016|accessdate=August 29, 2016}}</ref>
On September 21, 2016, the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' published an article claiming that Weiner had engaged in sexting with a 15-year-old girl.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3790824/Anthony-Weiner-carried-months-long-online-sexual-relationship-troubled-15-year-old-girl-telling-hard-asking-dress-school-girl-outfits-pressing-engage-rape-fantasies.html#ixzz4Ku1mvPVL|title=Anthony Weiner online sexual relationship with 15-year-old girl|publisher=dailymail.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/can-anthony-weiner-go-to-jail-for-sexting-a-15-year-old-w441525|title=Can Anthony Weiner Go to Jail for Sexting a 15-Year-Old Girl?|publisher=rollingstone.com}}</ref> It's not known how the ''Daily Mail'' learned of this incident as in the ''Daily Mail'' article the girl's father says he did not contact the police and this article was used as reason for the FBI and NYPD to begin investigating Weiner. Devices owned by Weiner and Abedin were seized as part of the investigation into this incident.<ref name="New York Times">{{Cite journal |title=New Emails in Clinton Case Came From Devices Once Used by Anthony Weiner |journal=The New York Times |date=October 28, 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/29/us/politics/fbi-hillary-clinton-email.html }}</ref> Emails pertinent to the [[Hillary Clinton email controversy]] were discovered on Weiner's laptop, prompting FBI Director [[James Comey]] to reopen that investigation late into the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 US presidential election]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/29/us/politics/fbi-hillary-clinton-email.html|title=Emails in Anthony Weiner Inquiry Jolt Hillary Clinton’s Campaign|work=The New York Times|last1=Goldman|last2=Rappeport|first1=Adam|first2=Alan|date=October 28, 2016|accessdate=May 19, 2017}}</ref> [[Hillary Clinton]] has cited Comey's decision as one reason why she lost the election to [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/13/us/politics/hillary-clinton-james-comey.html?_r=0|title=Hillary Clinton Blames F.B.I. Director for Election Loss|work=The New York Times|last=Chozick|first1=Amy|date=November 12, 2016|accessdate=May 19, 2017}}</ref>
On January 31, 2017, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that federal prosecutors were weighing whether to bring [[child pornography]] charges against Weiner over the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/prosecutors-weigh-child-pornography-charges-against-anthony-weiner-1485894771|title=Prosecutors Weigh Child-Pornography Charges Against Anthony Weiner|first1=Erica|last1=Orden|first2=Nicole|last2=Hong|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=January 31, 2017|accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref> On May 19, 2017, the ''[[New York Times]]'' reported Weiner had surrendered to the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] that morning, and under a [[plea bargain]] he intended to plead guilty to a single charge of transferring obscene material to a minor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/19/nyregion/anthony-weiner-guilty-plea-sexting.html|title=Anthony Weiner to Plead Guilty to Resolve ‘Sexting’ Inquiry |work=[[New York Times]]|date=May 19, 2017|accessdate=May 19, 2017}}</ref> Abedin reportedly filed for divorce prior to his guilty plea.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/19/politics/abedin-weiner-divorce/|title=Huma Abedin divorcing Anthony Weiner|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=May 19, 2017|accessdate=May 19, 2017}}</ref> On September 25, 2017, Judge Denise Cote of the Southern District of New York agreed to a plea agreement sentence totaling 21 months in federal prison, three years supervised release, and for Weiner to register as a sex offender.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2017/08/18/judge-postpones-weiners-sentencing-for-sexting-scandal/|title=Judge postpones Weiner’s sentencing for sexting scandal |work=[[New York Post]]|date=August 18, 2017|accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref> Weiner reported to [[Federal Medical Center, Devens]] on November 6.<ref>{{cite news |last=Casarez |first=Jean |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/06/us/weiner-reports-to-prison/index.html |title=Anthony Weiner reports to prison |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=November 6, 2017 |accessdate=November 7, 2017}}</ref>
==In popular culture== The first scandal was used as the inspiration for part of the plot line of Season I-II of the Showtime series ''[[Homeland (TV series)|Homeland]]'', where a protagonist, a war hero (played by [[Damian Lewis]]), is invited to run for Congress (and subsequently gets elected) after the political career of "Congressman Dick Johnson" comes to a sudden end after his sexting pictures are publicized. A ''[[Washington Post]]'' article, noting that the Weiner story broke just in time for script purposes, quotes [[Alex Gansa]], co-creator of ''Homeland'': "We were looking for a way that our lead character could become a congressman in a very quick period of time. This presented itself on a platter."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/post/homeland-does-it-get-washington-right/2011/11/15/gIQAAG4dPN_blog.html "'Homeland': Does it get Washington right?"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', November 15, 2011.</ref>
The 2016 documentary ''[[Weiner (film)|Weiner]]'' covers his resignation from Congress and his 2013 run for Mayor of New York City.<ref>[http://www.indiewire.com/2016/01/sundance-review-weiner-is-the-best-documentary-about-a-political-campaign-ever-made-32414/ Sundance Review: 'Weiner' is the Best Documentary About a Political Campaign Ever Made], Eric Kohn, Indie Wire, January 2016</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/jan/24/anthony-weiner-review-huma-abedin-documentary Weiner review: an unsparing portrait of politics], Lanre Bakare, The Guardian, January 24, 2016</ref>

{{wiktionary|globophobia}} '''Balloon phobia''' or '''globophobia''' is a fear of [[balloon]]s.<ref name=bmj>{{cite journal|last1=Brewer|first1=C.|title=Balloon phobia|journal=BMJ|date=5 November 2013|volume=347|issue=nov05 3|pages=f6652–f6652|doi=10.1136/bmj.f6652}}</ref> The source of fear may be the sound of balloons popping.<ref name=bmj/>
Generally, globophobics will refuse to touch, feel, or go near a balloon for fear it will pop.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Houlihan|first= D|last2= Schwartz|first2=C |date=September 1993 |title= The rapid treatment of a young man's balloon (noise) phobia using in vivo flooding. |journal= J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry | pmid = 8188847 |volume=24 |pages=233–40 |doi=10.1016/0005-7916(93)90026-s}}</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:Mental health]] [[Category:Phobias]] [[Category:Balloons (entertainment)]]

[[Image:7diamonds.gif|right]] In [[Trick-taking game|trick-taking card games]] like [[Contract bridge|bridge]], the '''beer card''' is the seven of diamonds ({{diamonds}}7) [[playing card]] when it is agreed that, if a player wins the last trick of a hand with the {{diamonds}}7, his partner must buy him a [[beer]]. It is not considered as part of the rules of these games, but an optional and informal side-bet between players. This practice is likely originated from Danish [[Tarot card games|Tarot]] or [[Skat (card game)|Skat]] in the middle of the 20th century.McLeod, John. [https://www.pagat.com/boston/bridge.html#beer Contract Bridge] at [[pagat.com]]. Retrieved 4 October 2016. ==Requirements== [[File:Card05.gif|thumb|right|''The Jack holding the 7 ♦'']] The requirements vary depending on whether the winner of the last trick is the declarer or a defender. In every case, though, the last trick must be won by {{diams}}7. For declarer, the requirements are generally that: *He must make the contract (exceptions may be made for a successful {{gcb|sacrifice|sacrifice}}) *Diamonds must not be trumps (though some people play that only diamond {{gcb|partscore|part-scores}}, and not games or slams, are excluded) *He must take a justifiable line to win as many tricks as possible For a defender, the requirements are generally that: *The contract must be defeated *Diamonds must not be trumps (though some people play that doubled contracts are excluded) *He and his partner must try to win as many tricks as possible *His partner must try to stop him winning the last trick with {{diams}}7 If the contract is doubled, then two beers are earned. If the contract is redoubled, then four beers are earned. ==Examples== {{Main|Contract bridge}} {{BridgeHandNS |7|Q 8 3 2|A K Q 10 9|Q 7 6 |Q 8 3 2|A K|J 7 3 2|A K 5}} South plays in the inferior contract of three notrump (6{{Diamonds}} is excellent), against which the opponents cash the first four spade tricks. To maximize the chance of getting a beer, declarer must discard two top diamond honors and a small heart from dummy. If the diamonds do not break 4-0, it is straightforward to cash nine winners, ending with the beer card. If the diamonds don't break, there's a chance that a defender will be pseudosqueezed and choose to discard a diamond. For declarer to discard three diamond honors risks losing the contract unnecessarily, and so forfeits the beer, even if diamonds turn out to break normally. Alternately, if North-South only exclude diamond partials from beer card enforcement, then the declarer in six diamonds can easily beer assuming trumps break. Declarer wins the (say) heart lead in the South hand and cashes one high trump in the North hand. When they break, declarer cashes two more high trumps, exits a spade, uses the rounded-suit entries to ruff two spades in the North hand, and finally trump the losing heart with the beer card. When they do not break, the simplest line (ruff a heart in the South hand) forces declarer to use the beer card while drawing trumps. {{Clear}} {{BridgeHandNS |A|A 8|A K 9 7 6 5|K Q 9 3 |K 10 8 7 6|9|Q 10 3|A J 7 6}} {| class="wikitable" style="float:left; margin-top:10px; margin-right:10px;" !West||North||East||South |- align=center | ||1{{Diamonds}} ||Pass ||1{{Spades}} |- align=center |2{{Hearts}} ||3{{Hearts}} ||Pass ||4{{Clubs}} |- align=center |Pass ||4NT ||Pass||5{{Clubs}} |- align=center |Pass ||7{{Clubs}}||Dbl|| Pass |- align=center |Pass||Pass|||| |} Note that the four notrump bid is the modern Roman Keycard Blackwood with 1430 responses and clubs as trumps. South won the {{Hearts}}K lead in dummy, drew trumps in three rounds and played a diamond to the ace. When both minors broke, South ruffed the remaining heart in hand and claimed his doubled grand slam along with the beers. Plus 2330, two beers, and 14 IMPs. In theory, South should have interpreted the final double as a Lightner double and removed to seven diamonds. However, given that his priorities placed the probable doubled beer ahead of trusting the opponents, he should still not redouble. Since the opponents were non-vulnerable, it just may have occurred to them to remove to seven hearts. While the sacrifice rates to go down two thousand, there is certainly no hope for even North to score the beer. {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== {{commons|Category:7 of Diamonds}} *[[List of playing-card nicknames]] ==External links== *[http://www.bridgeguys.com/sec/glossary/b/index.html Bridge Glossary "B"] *[http://www.nswba.com.au/youth/ybeer.html NSW Bridge Association] {{WPCBIndex}} {{Playing cards}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beer Card}} [[Category:Contract bridge card play]] [[Category:Playing cards]] [[Category:Card game terminology]] [[Category:Drinking card games]]

revision.text:
The '''British Columbia Film Classification Office''' is part of the Business Practices and Consumer Protection Authority in the [[Canadian province]] of [[British Columbia]] under the Motion Picture Act (MP Act) of BC. The BCFCO film ratings are also used by [[Saskatchewan]] under the terms of a bilateral agreement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saskjustice.gov.sk.ca/film_&_video/ |title=Film and Video Classification Board |publisher=[[Saskatchewan Ministry of Justice]] |accessdate=2007-04-30 |quote=On October 1, 1997, an agreement between the province of British Columbia and Saskatchewan came into effect, under which the [http://www.bcfilmclass.com/ British Columbia Film Classification Office] will classify all new theatrical releases and adult videos on behalf of the Saskatchewan Film and Video Classification Board. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220150000/http://www.saskjustice.gov.sk.ca/film_%26_video/ |archivedate=2007-02-20 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Beginning on January 1, 1997, the BCFCO used the following [[motion picture rating system]] (based on the [[Canadian Home Video Rating System]]) for [[theatrical]] releases:
* '''General'''. Suitable for viewing by persons of all ages. Occasional violence, swearing and coarse language, and the most innocent of sexually suggestive scenes and nudity, are permitted in this category. (Similar to the [[MPAA film rating system|US rating]] or the lower end of the PG rating) * '''Parental Guidance'''. Parental guidance advised. Theme or content may not be suitable for all children although there is no age restriction. Motion pictures in this category may contain less subtle sexually suggestive scenes and nudity and a more realistic portrayal of violence than in the General category; coarse language may occur more often than in the General category. * '''14A'''. Suitable for persons 14 years of age or older. Persons under 14 years of age must view these motion pictures accompanied by an adult. Motion pictures in this category may contain violence, coarse language or sexually suggestive scenes, or any combination of them. * '''18A'''. Persons under 18 years of age must view these motion pictures accompanied by an adult. Motion pictures in this category will contain horror, explicit violence, frequent coarse language or scenes that are more sexually suggestive than in the 14A category, or any combination of them. * '''Restricted'''. Restricted to persons 18 years of age and over. Persons under 18 years of age are not permitted to attend under any circumstances. These motion pictures are "adult motion pictures", as defined in the Act, and may contain explicit sexual scenes, violence or scenes referred to in Section 5(3) of the Act, or any combination of them. The director will assign this classification to motion pictures if the director considers that the theme, subject matter or plot of the adult motion picture is artistic, historical, political, educational or scientific. * '''Adult''' - Restricted to persons 18 years of age and over. Persons under 18 years of age are not permitted to attend under any circumstances. These motion pictures are "adult motion pictures", as defined in the Act, and may contain explicit sexual scenes or scenes of brutality or torture to persons or animals, or any combination of them, that are portrayed in a realistic and explicit manner; however, the scenes would, in the director's opinion, be tolerable to the community.
Titles in the "Restricted" and "Adult" categories have labelling and/or display restrictions under the Motion Picture Act for home video retailing purposes, but not those rated 18A or below.
The B.C. Film Classification Office originated the ''restricted cougar'' symbol in the 1970s as an icon that audiences could easily associate with the "Restricted" category. The B.C. Film Classification Office ''chose the cougar not only for its dramatic presence but also its significance as the largest wild cat native to BC''.<ref>[http://www.bcfilmclass.com/cougar/index.htm BC Film Classification Office Cougar symbol] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202101847/http://www.bcfilmclass.com/cougar/index.htm |date=February 2, 2007 }} Retrieved 24 March 2007</ref>
==Sources== <!--<nowiki> See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref> and </ref> tags, and the template below. </nowiki>--><references/>
==External links== * {{official}}
{{Media regulation and recognition in Canada}}

{{infobox organization |name = Cinemateca Uruguaya |type = [[Cinematheque]] |formation = {{Start date and age|1952|04|21}} |founder = '''Cine Universitario:'''
Walther Dassori Barthet
Jaime Francisco Botet
Jorge Ángel Arteaga
Selva Airaldi
'''Cine Club del Uruguay:'''
Eugenio Hintz
Alberto Mántaras Rogé
José Carlos Álvarez |region = Uruguay |leader_title = Awards |leader_name = [[Premio Morosoli]] |website = [http://www.cinemateca.org.uy/index.htm cinemateca.org.uy] |predecessor = Cine Universitario
Cine Club del Uruguay }} '''Cinemateca Uruguaya''' (''Uruguayan Cinematheque'') is a non-profit [[cinematheque]] in [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]], established in 1952, that aims to support the cultural development of [[Cinematography|cinema]], and of art in general. Since its inception, it has belonged to the [[International Federation of Film Archives]] (FIAF). It is also a founding member of the Latin American Coordinating Committee of Moving Image Archives (CLAIM), and advisory member of the Audiovisual and Film Institute of Uruguay (ICAU).{{cita web |url = http://www.cinemateca.org.uy/institucional.html |title = Institucional |author = Cinemateca Uruguaya |access-date = 15 December 2014}} By the end of the twentieth century, its archive held 11,500 films, including over 2,000 Uruguayan works.[http://www.oei.org.co/sii/entrega6/art05.htm Un archivo muy elocuente] {{es icon}} ({{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/62bXwCPAV?url=http://www.oei.org.co/sii/entrega6/art05.htm |date=October 21, 2011 }}) In 1995, Cinemateca Uruguaya received the Premio Morosoli, an Uruguayan cultural award. It was designated Cultural Heritage of the City of Montevideo.Resolución de la Junta Departamental de Montevideo de 10 de agosto de 1998. In October 1998, its importance as an educational institution was recognized by the Faculty of Humanities and Educational Science of the [[University of the Republic (Uruguay)|University of the Republic]], and it was categorized as an educational and cultural institution by the Ministry of Education and Culture of Uruguay. Its film archive was declared a national historic monument by the Heritage Commission and the ICAU Resolución del Poder Ejecutivo de 5 de octubre de 1999., and its activities were declared of departmental and cultural interest to the city of Montevideo.Resolución n.º 5339/07 de la Intendencia Municipal de Montevideo de 24 de diciembre de 2007. == Areas of activity == [[File:Marca de la memoria - Cinemateca Uruguaya.jpg|thumbnail|254x254px|Headquarters of Cinemateca Uruguaya]] Its areas of activity include:[http://www.rau.edu.uy/uruguay/cultura/Cinemateca.htm Cinemateca.htm] *'''Film Preservation'''. Facilities in the outskirts of Montevideo store archived materials at optimal temperature and humidity. *'''School of Cinema'''. Offers grade school, post graduate, and extracurricular courses. *'''Cinemas.''' Four venues in Montevideo: Cinemateca 18, Sala Pocitos Hall, Sala Cinemateca and Sala 2. * '''Cinematographic Documentation Center.''' Includes collections of books, magazines and journals, newspaper articles, photos, posters, and other media. Cinemateca Uruguaya also organizes the [[Festival Cinematográfico Internacional del Uruguay|International Cinema Festival of Uruguay]], which in 2018 marked its 36th year. == See also == * [[Cinema of Uruguay]] * [[List of film archives]] * [[Cinematheque]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cinemateca.org.uy Cinemateca Uruguaya's website] (in Spanish only) *[http://www.ecu.edu.uy Cinema School of Uruguay] [[Category:Film archives]] [[Category:Culture in Montevideo]] [[Category:Archives in Uruguay]] [[Category:Cinemas and movie theaters]] [[Category:Cinema of Uruguay]] [[Category:1952 establishments in Uruguay]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1952]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Down in the Dumps | image = Downinthedumps boxshot.jpg | caption = Cover art for ''Down in the Dumps''. | developer = [[Haiku Studios]] | publisher = [[Philips Media]] | designer = | released = {{vgrelease|EU|[[1996 in video gaming|1996]]}} | genre = [[Adventure game]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | platforms = [[MS-DOS]], [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Macintosh]] }} '''''Down in the Dumps''''' is a 1996 computer [[adventure game]] developed for [[MS-DOS]] and [[Microsoft Windows]], by the [[France|French]] [[Haiku Studios]] and published by [[Philips Media]]. The release for [[Macintosh]] was published in 1997. Versions for the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]], [[Sega Saturn]] and [[Philips CD-i]]<ref>http://cdii.blogspot.nl/2007/05/down-in-dumps-cancelled-on-cd-i.html</ref> were slated for 1996,<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Down in the Dumps |journal=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |issue=83|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=June 1996 |page=96}}</ref> but never released.
==Story== [[Image:Downinthedumps screenshot01.jpg|thumb|140px|left|Game interface]] The game's storyline is about the Blubs, an [[Extraterrestrial life in popular culture|extraterrestrial]] family (father and mother Blub, their son and daughter, the grandparents and their pet Stinkie), who crash with their [[starship|spaceship]] on a [[landfill]] on [[Earth]] after being pursued by the villainous Khan and his criminal associates. After surviving the crash, the Blub family goes on to live on the landfill, while trying to repair their damaged spaceship in order to return home. The player is set out on a mission by grandfather Blub, an inventor and the spaceship's technician, to find the missing parts needed to reconstruct the spaceship. Meanwhile, Khan, whose ship also crashed on the landfill after the pursuit of the Blub family, sends out his minions to frustrate the efforts of the Blubs.
==Style== [[Image:Downinthedumps screenshot02.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Screenshot showing the visual style and quality of the [[cutscenes]]]] The game consists of five parts called "toons", all set in the landfill – except for part five which takes place in space – featuring one or two of the Blub family members as playable characters. The five sections are titled "The Blub, the Rat and the Bad Guy", "The Hypnotic Machine", "The Abominable Robin Blub", "The Bum" and "The End". Each has its own distinct visual theme, although the overall visual style is very [[cartoon]]-like. For example, the player visits the head of a [[homeless person]] ("bum") and a society inhabited by [[frog]]s, where a series of events somewhat reminiscent of the [[Robin Hood]] story is triggered.
The player has to solve different puzzles in order to advance the plot by using a [[point and click]] interface. Large portions of the plot are told by [[pre-rendered]] [[Cutscene|cinematic]]s, often triggered at the beginning or the end of a "toon".
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/19961225045749/http://www.haikustudios.com/ |date=December 25, 1996 |title=Haiku Studios Official website }} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/19970327141607/http://www.haikustudios.com/frames/did.htm |date=March 27, 1997 |title=Down in the Dumps on HaikuStudios.com }} * [http://www.csoon.com/issue23/downdump.htm ComingSoon Review] * [http://www.gameboomers.com/reviews/Dd/DowndumpsbySinger.htm GameBoomers Review] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060512222507/http://www.a-for-adventure.com/gamereview.php?id=239 A for Adventure Review] *{{moby game|id=/down-in-the-dumps|name=''Down in the Dumps''}}

{{Infobox film | name = Dragon Seed | image = Dragon-seed-1944.jpg | image_size = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Harold S. Bucquet]]
[[Jack Conway (film-maker)|Jack Conway]] | producer = [[Pandro S. Berman]] | writer = [[Marguerite Roberts]]
[[Jane Murfin]] | based on = {{based on|''[[Dragon Seed (novel)|Dragon Seed]]''
1943 novel|[[Pearl S. Buck]]}} | starring = [[Katharine Hepburn]]
[[Aline MacMahon]] | music = [[Herbert Stothart]] | cinematography = Sidney Wagner | editing = [[Harold F. Kress]] | distributor = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]
[[Loew's]] | released = {{Film date|1944|7|20}} | runtime = 147 min. | country = United States | language = English | budget = $3,070,000{{Citation | title = The Eddie Mannix Ledger | publisher = Margaret Herrick Library, Center for Motion Picture Study | place = Los Angeles}}. | gross = $4,627,000 }} '''''Dragon Seed''''' is a 1944 [[war film|war]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] starring [[Katharine Hepburn]]. Based on a best-selling [[Dragon Seed (novel)|book]] by [[Pearl S. Buck]], the film portrays a peaceful village in [[China]] that has been invaded by the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] during the [[Second Sino-Japanese war]]. The men in the village choose to adopt a peaceful attitude toward their conquerors; but the headstrong Jade (Hepburn) stands up to the Japanese. [[Aline MacMahon]] was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for Best Supporting Actress. ==Plot== A peaceful Chinese village is invaded by the Japanese prior to World War II. The men elect to adopt a peaceful attitude towards their conquerors and it is understood that the women will stoically acquiesce as well. But Jade ([[Katharine Hepburn]]), a headstrong young woman, intends to stand up to the Japanese whether her husband Lao Er ([[Turhan Bey]]) approves or not. She even goes so far as to learn to read and to handle a weapon, so that she may be properly equipped for both psychological and physical combat. Jade's attitude spreads to the rest of the village, convincing even the staunchest of male traditionalists that the Japanese can be defeated only by offering a strong united front; male and female.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/dragon-seed-v14685|title=Dragon Seed (1944) - Harold S. Bucquet, Jack Conway - Synopsis, Characteristics, Moods, Themes and Related - AllMovie|website=AllMovie}} ==Cast== * [[Katharine Hepburn]] as Jade * [[Walter Huston]] as Ling Tan * [[Aline MacMahon]] as Ling Tan's Wife * [[Akim Tamiroff]] as Wu Lien * [[Turhan Bey]] as Lao Er Tan * [[Hurd Hatfield]] as Lao San Tan * [[J. Carrol Naish]] as Japanese Kitchen Overseer * [[Agnes Moorehead]] as Third Cousin's Wife * [[Henry Travers]] as Third Cousin * [[Robert Bice]] as Lao Ta Tan * [[Robert Lewis (actor)|Robert Lewis]] as Captain Sato * [[Frances Rafferty]] as Orchid Tan * [[Leonard Strong (actor)|Leonard Strong]] as a Japanese Official * [[Jacqueline deWit]] as Wu Lien's Wife * [[Clarence Lung]] as Fourth Cousin * [[Paul E. Burns]] as Neighbor Shen * [[Anna Demetrio]] as Wu Sao ==Box office== According to MGM records the film earned $3,033,000 in the US and Canada and $1,594,000 elsewhere but because of its high cost incurred a loss to the studio of $281,000. ==See also== * [[Whitewashing in film]] *[[List of American films of 1944]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{IMDb title|0036777|Dragon Seed}} * {{tcmdb title|http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/131/Dragon-Seed|Dragon Seed}} * {{Amg movie|14685|Dragon Seed}} * {{AFI film|id=2198|title=Dragon Seed}} {{Jane Murfin}} {{Harold S. Bucquet}} {{Jack Conway}} [[Category:1944 films]] [[Category:1940s drama films]] [[Category:American war drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films based on American novels]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Second Sino-Japanese War films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jack Conway]] [[Category:Films directed by Harold S. Bucquet]] [[Category:Films set in China]] [[Category:World War II films made in wartime]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films scored by Herbert Stothart]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Jane Murfin]] [[Category:Films based on works by Pearl S. Buck]] {{war-drama-film-stub}}

{{Infobox video game | title = Dungeon Master: Theron's Quest | image = Dungeon Master - Theron's Quest cover.png | image_size = 250px | developer = [[FTL Games]]
Software Heaven
[[Beam Software]] | publisher = [[Victor Interactive Software]] | designer = | released = {{vgrelease|JP|September 18, 1992|NA|1993}} | genre = [[Role-playing video game]] | modes = [[Single player]] | platforms = [[TurboGrafx CD]] }} '''''Dungeon Master: Theron's Quest''''' is a modified version of ''[[Dungeon Master (video game)|Dungeon Master]]'' for the [[TurboGrafx]]/[[PC Engine]] video game console.{{cite web |url=http://www.meanmachinesmag.co.uk/upload/media/scans/retrogamer_dungeonmaster.pdf |title=The Making of Dungeon Master|last=McFerran|first=Damien|work=Issue 34 |year=2006 |publisher=[[Retro Gamer]] Magazine |pages=30–31|accessdate=2011-01-19}} It was released on September 18, 1992 in Japan, with a North American release following the next year.{{moby game|id=/dungeon-master-therons-quest|name=''Dungeon Master: Theron's Quest''}} The main goal of the game is Theron finding seven parts of a blue [[knight]]'s [[armor]] (Shield Defiant, Taza Poleyn, Tazahelm, Taza Boots, Taza Armor, Soulcage, The Retaliator), each of which is located in one of seven mini dungeons.[http://dmweb.free.fr/?q=node/252 Dungeon Master Encyclopaedia] == Differences from the original == [[image:Dungeon Master - Theron's Quest in-game screenshot (PC Engine).png|thumb|left|In the Hall of Champions]] It has a different story, but can be considered as a light version of Dungeon Master. Theron's Quest doesn't contain all of the items, spells and monsters featured in Dungeon Master. Theron's Quest contains seven small dungeons instead of one big dungeon, which however are partially identical or inspired by the original dungeons of Dungeon Master and [[Chaos Strikes Back]]. As in the original, the player goes on a quest with a team of up to four champions fighting through dungeons gaining experience and finding items. In contrast to the original, the player takes the role of a character named Theron and three other champions. After successful completion of each dungeon, the whole party loses its collected items and the three champions lose their skills and statistics. Further, the game can only be saved between dungeons. The lack of the original save option during a level has been replaced by many resurrection 'Altars of VI'. There are also fewer monsters to fight which renders the game easier than the original. ==Reception== Upon the game's release, all but one of ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'''s four reviewers remarked that ''Dungeon Master'', despite having aged badly over the years, remains a solid RPG. The remaining reviewer stated that [[dungeon crawl]]s "just isn't my type of game." The reviewers generally praised the new CD-quality soundtrack and gave the game a score of 6.5 out of 10.{{cite journal|last= |first= |title=Review Crew: Dungeon Master|journal=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]|issue=47|publisher=EGM Media, LLC|date=June 1993|page=36}} == See also == * ''[[Dungeon Master (video game)|Dungeon Master]]'' * ''[[Dungeon Master: Chaos Strikes Back]]'' * ''[[Dungeon Master II: The Legend of Skullkeep]]'' * ''[[Dungeon Master Nexus]]'' * [[FTL Games]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{moby game|id=/dungeon-master-therons-quest|name=''Dungeon Master: Theron's Quest''}} * [http://dmweb.free.fr/?q=node/252 Dungeon Master Encyclopaedia] {{Dungeon Master series}} [[Category:Role-playing video games]] [[Category:Action role-playing video games]] [[Category:First-person party-based dungeon crawler video games]] [[Category:TurboGrafx-CD games]] [[Category:TurboGrafx-CD-only games]] [[Category:Fantasy video games]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:1992 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]]

{{about||flagging in marching bands|Color guard (flag spinning)|Italian flagging art|Flag throwing}}
{{context|date=August 2018}} {{more footnotes|date=April 2008}} [[Image:XMen Flags.jpg|frame|right|A flag dancer at a nightclub: circa 2001.]] [[File:Exemplo de flagger girando suas bandeiras.jpg|thumb|Example (2011)]]
The art of '''flagging dance''', often called '''flag spinning''', '''flag dancing''', or '''rag spinning''', but more commonly referred to as '''flagging''', is the undulation, spinning and waving of flags in a rhythmic fashion to music. Practitioners of this form of performance art and dance are usually referred to as "flaggers" and "flag dancers", though until the 1990s this mostly referred to those waving flags to aid transportation professions ([[flag semaphore]]).
== Origins == Modern-day flagging in the [[United States]] developed from [[fan dancing]], which was prominent in the [[leather subculture]] and later circuit parties of [[Fire Island Pines, New York|Fire Island]] and [[Manhattan]] in the 1970s.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Fierce Tribe: Masculine Identity and Performance in the Circuit|last = Weems|first = Mickey|publisher = Utah State University Press|year = 2008|isbn = 978-0-87421-691-2|location = Logan, Utah|pages = 51}}</ref>
==Rebirth== The flaggers and fan dancers almost disappeared as AIDS took its toll on the community<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://flowaffair.org/index.html|title=The Evolution of Flag Dancing - Flow Affair, Flagging and Fanning dance|website=flowaffair.org|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref>, but by 1988 a few masters of these arts ensured they passed their tradition onto new members of the community. Adam Wojtowicz (flags) and Jeffrey Reichlin (fans) were two such performance artists in the New York area first seen at The Saint at Large. Three performed for [[Heritage of Pride]] in 1990, four in 1991. In 1996 thirty fan dancers and flaggers from the Northeast where ready to take rotations on stage at the annual Pride Dance on the Pier.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gaycenter.org/archive_item/heritage-of-pride-records/|title=Heritage of Pride Records {{!}} The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center|date=2018-02-14|work=The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en-US}}</ref> San Francisco, where this art form began, was still recovering from its loses. Those who had not died, placed their toys away out of significant grief. [[AmfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research|AmFAR]] held a benefit in September 1997 at the [[Trocadero, San Francisco|Trocadero]] returning the dance to its birthplace.
==Contemporary flags== The origins of flagging started with simple tee-shirts on the dance floor or fabric with a quarter tied in one corner. Today they are made by adding curtain weights sewn onto portions of two sides of fabric make it possible for flaggers to spin their props, or toys, through the air in ways similar to fan dancing. Given their simpler design (and portability), flagging is easier for beginners to start with and one can purchase pre-made flags from a few artisans such as Don Baker. The first such opportunity was advertised in Circuit Noize magazine in 1997– simple gold lame flags of 3 feet by 5 feet that came with a matching bag. Flags can be of almost any fabric, but silk, organza and lamé are preponderant, with silk being the most favored. Silk flags are usually dyed in vibrant, [[ultraviolet]] [[fluorescent]] colors, creating an almost hypnotic spectacle when spun rhythmically to music.
==Flagging tribes in the USA== Flagger groups, known as tribes, formed in [[New York City]], [[Boston]], [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Washington, D.C.|DC]], [[Los Angeles]], [[San Francisco]] and [[South Florida]] in the mid 1990s, and were often part of the backdrop of the [[circuit party]] events mostly attended by [[gay men]]. These were soon followed by the formation of troupes in [[Minneapolis]], [[Seattle]], and [[Houston]] in the United States, and in [[Belo Horizonte]], [[Brazil]]. Of these, two chose to commercialize this disco art form and operated as choreographed performance troupes: Axis Danz in New York the FlyBoys of Flag in Texas. Many tribes continue to perform as atmosphere in clubs and at benefits worldwide.
==Flagging In Brazil== The origins of this art in Brazil date back to [[Belo Horizonte]], a city of the state of [[Minas Gerais]], 1998 - 1999. Due to the abundance of gay festivities in the country, the culture initially spread to [[Rio de Janeiro]] and later to [[São Paulo]], [[Brasília]] and [[Florianópolis]]. Many users of social networks (Facebook, Orkut, among others) posted their photos with banners (flags) to promote and / or demonstrate the art. There are some meetings in the park that are held to provide opportunities to practice, similar to those in the USA. Some of them even sponsored by the city (laws to encourage Culture, in Belo Horizonte). These are usually organized by art masters (flag masters) in some cities such as Belo Horizonte or São Paulo. Another city, Florianopolis, has seen an increase of flagging activities at festivals and parties since 2010. These events promote the exchange of experiences among the participants, ensuring the continued maintenance of Art and Culture with Flags on the national scene. On July 9, 2011, the fourth Minas Gerais flaggers meeting took place in Belo Horizonte, where several members of the country participated. It is the second largest meeting of Flaggers in the world, second only to the community of the city of San Francisco, California. Currently, this art can be seen in electronic culture scenes such as Raves in various parts of the country. The flags are not necessarily manufactured by flag-makers originating in Brazil by the original flaggers, but flags still continue to enter the scene through outside sources.
==Flagger events== Performances and conferences have begun forming in various cities, including New York, San Francisco and Dallas. Conferences and workshops happen in 2 or 3 full day events, and teach construction and techniques from beginner to advanced. A short list of leaders in the community often travel to many of these events, becoming known internationally as masters in Flag Dancing.
The Texas Flagger Weekend ran from 2003 - 2009. The event consisted of growing number of flaggers from around the world, peaking in 2008 with 80+ participants. The event had various tracks, from beginners to advanced. In later years, the Weekend expanded to include multiple tracks, a [[circuit party]] and a showcase of performances, SpinOut, of their own, inspired by the [[San Francisco]] events of the same name. The [[Texas]] Flagger Weekend was founded by Patric Nast and Phillip Bryan in [[Dallas]] in 2003.
New York hosted the "World Symposium of Fanning and Flagging" in 2005 and included movement classes, creation workshops, and performances, mostly held at [[The Center]].
Flagging In The Park (FITP), started in 1997, is a fundraising gathering of flaggers, flow artists, and their supporters, happening in the [[National AIDS Memorial Grove]] in [[Golden Gate Park]]. The event was started as a celebration of life and an honoring of those who had passed by founder Jeff Kennedy; then held by a few core members of the close-knit SF Tribe; in 2002 - 2003 the event was produced in [[Dolores Park]] by Bryan Hughes; in 2005 the event moved back to the National AIDS Memorial Grove being led by Xavier Caylor; from 2014 to the present the event is being held by a group of flaggers from the Bay Area and beyond. The basic event includes: a live DJ spinning music, a time for reflection, and hat being passed to raise money money for charity. Flaggers, [[Fan dance|Fan Dancers]], [[Poi (performance art)|Poi]], and [[Hoop dancing|Hoop dancers]] are all invited to the event. One of the five events happens the last full weekend of July, on Saturday before the [[Up Your Alley Street Fair]] on Sunday, and is advertised as the (Flagger) SF Destination Weekend. The weekend offers a tie-dye opportunity (flag creation), FITP, and several opportunities to gather with and without flags; the other 4 dates vary - check www.flagginginthepark.org for more information.
== Sources == * Genre Magazine, June 2004 *''[[New York Blade]]'', February 6, 2004 * [http://www.edgeonthenet.com/nightlife/parties///122989/new_film_documents_history_&_artistry_of_flagging/ Edge Magazine], review of Flow Affair documentary by Jim Hauk, August 3, 2011. * Xavier Caylor, Producer of Flagging In The Park 1999 to present, August 2018

{{Infobox government agency |name = Games and Amusements Board |native_name = ''Lupon sa mga Laro at Libangan'' |type = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |logo = Games and Amusement Board (GAB).svg |logo_width = |logo_caption = |image = |image_size = |image_caption = |formed = {{start date|1951}} |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = Philippines |headquarters = [[Makati]], [[Metro Manila]] |coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LATITUDE|LONGITUDE|type:landmark_region:US|display=inline,title}} --> |motto = |budget = |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_department = [[Office of the President (Philippines)|Office of the President]] |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{URL|http://gab.gov.ph/}} |footnotes = }} The '''Games and Amusements Board''' ('''GAB''') ({{lang-tgl|Lupon sa mga Laro at Libangan}}) is the government-ran regulatory body of professional sports in the Philippines.<ref name="about">{{cite web|title=Games and Amusements Board|url=http://gab.gov.ph/games-and-amusements-board/|website=Games and Amusements Board|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
==History== The Games and Amusements Board initially started its operation in 1951 with the issuance of Executive Order No. 392. Through this particular law, the powers, duties and functions previously exercised, and performed by:<ref name="historical">{{cite web|title=Historical Background|publisher=Games and Amusements Board|url=http://gab.gov.ph/historical-background/|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
#the city and municipal mayors over fronton and basque pelota games #the Boxing and Wrestling Commission over boxing and wrestling #the [[Philippine Racing Commission]] (PRC) over horse racing, were consolidated and transferred to the Board
On March 20, 1974, the authority over horse racing was divided between the Board and the PRC.<ref name="historical"/>
On January 6, 1976, the scope of GAB’s regulatory function over professional sports widened as the agency was tasked to likewise supervise and regulate the professional [[basketball]] and other professional games in the country.<ref name="historical"/>
The Board’s regulatory function was also made more specific against anti-illegal gambling operations with the establishment of Anti-Illegal Gambling Unit (AIGU) in January 17, 1992 – which became one of GAB’s units. AIGU initially was composed of personnel appointed by the Chairman of GAB and detailed staff from the [[Philippine National Police]], the [[National Bureau of Investigation (Philippines)|National Bureau of Investigation]], the Philippine Racing Commission, the [[Philippine Charity Sweepstakes Office]], other offices involved in gambling operations, as well as other law enforcement agencies in the country. On December 28, 1993, the board assumed part of the overall functions of the Gamefowl Commission, particularly insofar as international [[cockfight]] derbies are concerned.<ref name="historical"/>
==Leadership== GAB, as an organization, is headed by a chairman and two commissioners<ref name="historical"/>
==Scope== ===Sports and activities=== Among professional sports and activities that the GAB regulates are: ;Sports *[[Association football]]<ref name=PFL>{{cite news|title=GAB grants PFL professional license|url=http://www.foxsportsasia.com/en-ph/news/gab-grants-pfl-professional-license/|accessdate=6 May 2017|work=Fox Sports Philippines|date=3 May 2017}}</ref> *[[professional boxing|Boxing]]<ref name="about"/> (including [[Women's boxing|women's]]<ref name="historical"/>) *[[Basketball]]<ref name="about"/> *[[Billiards]]<ref name="historical"/> *[[Bowling]]<ref name="historical"/> *[[eSports]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sheldon|first1=David|title=Philippines Officially Recognizes eSports As A Real Sport|url=https://www.casino.org/blog/philippines-officially-recognizes-esports-as-a-real-sport/|accessdate=22 October 2017|work=Casino Org|date=22 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="abs-cbn">{{cite news|last1=Regalado|first1=Pia|title=The Philippines' new athletes: eSports gamers|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/focus/10/10/17/the-philippines-new-athletes-esports-gamers|accessdate=22 October 2017|work=ABS-CBN News|date=10 October 2017}}</ref> *[[Karate]]<ref name="about"/> *[[Mixed martial arts]]<ref name="historical"/> *[[Tennis]]<ref name="historical"/> *[[Table tennis]]<ref name="historical"/> *[[Professional wrestling|Wrestling]]<ref name="about"/>
;Other activities *[[Cockfighting]]<ref name="about"/> *[[horse racing]] [[betting]]<ref name="about"/>
It is also mandated to crack down against illegal gambling practices in professional sports.<ref name="about"/> ===Leagues=== {{incomplete section|date=November 2018}} The following are sports league which are holders of a professional license with the GAB. *[[Philippines Football League]]<ref name=PFL/>
GAB considers leagues where participating athletes "play for pay" should be under its supervisions under its mandate. In November 2018, the GAB has announced plans to put leagues which meets this criteria under its supervision such as the [[Maharlika Pilipinas Basketball League]], and the volleyball leagues [[Philippine Super Liga]] and [[Premier Volleyball League]] despite some of the leagues' players still simultaneously playing in collegiate leagues.<ref>{{cite news |title=GAB Chairman warns commercial leagues |url=https://sports.mb.com.ph/2018/11/23/gab-chairman-warns-commercial-leagues/ |accessdate=23 November 2018 |work=Manila Bulletin |date=23 November 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
